Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long duration snowfall. Additional snowfall: 10 to 25 cm Locations: Rigolet and vicinity. Time span: tonight into Wednesday night Remarks: Snow will continue overnight and Wednesday before tapering off Wednesday night. Strong northwesterly winds tonight and Wednesday will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow over exposed areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values near minus 55 will moderate tonight as temperatures slowly rise. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this evening through Wednesday afternoon. Lake effect snow off of Lake Superior will begin this evening. Snowfall rates may reach 1 to 3 centimeters per hour at times overnight through to Wednesday afternoon. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 centimeters are forecast by Wednesday evening. The heaviest snow will occur between Wawa and Nipigon, so expect poor travel conditions along this stretch of Highway 17. Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions. Visibility may be significantly reduced in heavy snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T12:45:21-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of snowfall is expected. Locations: Cartwright to Lodge Bay. Additional snowfall: 25 - 30 cm with higher amounts inland Wednesday evening. Time span: continuing until Thursday morning. Remarks: Snow, heavy at times, will continue tonight and Wednesday. The highest accumulations are expected over inland areas. Temperatures will be around the freezing mark along the coast, which could cause some melting to occur, resulting in reduced accumulations. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, blowing snow and strong winds are forecast. Additional snowfall amounts: 10 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland. Time span: until Wednesday afternoon or evening. Remarks: as temperatures fall below freezing this evening, snow will combine with strong winds to reduce visibility in blowing snow. Occasional to frequent whiteout conditions are likely, especially over exposed areas where blowing snow will be more intense. Strongest wind gusts will occur over the Port au Port Peninsula and areas south to Channel-Port aux Basques. Winds will begin to weaken on Wednesday morning. Conditions will begin to improve for some areas on Wednesday afternoon as snow changes to flurries, which will eventually taper off overnight on Wednesday night. Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-16T11:15:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T19:16:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0875722285.2020
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Today, visibilities will be poor and near zero at times in snow and blowing snow. These poor weather conditions will continue until Wednesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High water levels expected. Locations: eastern Newfoundland. Time span: Wednesday to Thursday. Remarks: Higher than normal water levels are likely during the high tide of Wednesday morning and possible during Thursday morning due to a combination of storm surge and large waves. At this time, the chance of any significant coastal flooding remains low. However, a change in atmospheric conditions could result in the need for a storm surge warning for coastal areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected. Snowfall tonight: 5 to 10 cm. Snowfall Wednesday: 15 to 25 cm. Snowfall Wednesday night: near 10 cm Locations: Postville and Makkovik. Remarks: Snow will become heavy, at times, on Wednesday. Temperatures along the coast will remain near the freezing mark throughout this event, which could result in reduced accumulations. Higher snowfall amounts are possible inland and over higher terrain. Strong winds could cause reduced visibility in blowing snow over exposed areas on Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific frontal system had brought near 10 cm of snow to Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass today. Further snow accumulations of 10 cm are expected tonight. Meanwhile, another Pacific front will approach the Kootenays tomorrow. Snow from the system will start tomorrow afternoon and will intensify tomorrow night with up to 20 cm of snow expected by Thursday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T14:59:06-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Flurries, snowsqualls, and blowing snow are expected to continue. Total snowfall: in excess of 30 centimetres by Wednesday evening. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 90 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: tonight and Wednesday. Remarks: snowfall rates will begin to diminish through the day on Wednesday as the winds begin to ease. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Wednesday. A narrow band of lake effect snow is expected to develop off Lake Ontario Tuesday overnight and move inland early Wednesday morning. This band will be over the Burlington area early Wednesday morning and slowly shift northwards reaching the southwestern section of the City of Toronto by mid morning. Through the afternoon the band will drift south, reaching downtown Hamilton in the evening. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible by Wednesday overnight with snowfall rates of several centimeters per hour likely. Under the lake effect bands heavy bursts of snow and blowing snow can significantly reduce visibilities. Motorists are advised to exercise caution and be prepared for quickly changing driving conditions. Consider postponing non essential travel as snow covered and icy roads are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T12:30:02-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall may occur on Thursday. Locations: most of mainland Nova Scotia Time span: Beginning Thursday morning and ending early Friday morning. Remarks: There is considerable uncertainty as to the amount of snowfall these regions will receive. However, current indications are that there is the potential for accumulations greater than 15 cm to occur in some areas of mainland Nova Scotia Thursday. As with most storms that pass south of Nova Scotia, a small difference in the forecast track will could result in a significant change in the snowfall forecast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

Strong northwesterly winds tonight and Wednesday will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow over exposed areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: westerly near 100 km/h. Locations: the Burin and Connaigre peninsulas. Time span: beginning this evening and lasting until Wednesday morning. Remarks: The strongest winds will occur over southern areas of both peninsulas, especially over areas exposed to the west. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2020-12-15. Higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected near the coast until late this afternoon. An intense low pressure system near Newfoundland will cause very strong to high winds in the regions listed below listed below. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of high tidal range could cause minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near the following locales, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Kamouraska - Rivi√®re-du-Loup - Trois-Pistoles: 2020-12-15, from 01:00 PM to 4:30 PM. Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2020-12-15, from 12:30 PM to 04:00 PM. Matane: 2020-12-15, from 12:30 PM to 04:00 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-15T23:59:29-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 35 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: today into Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow will become heavy, at times, Wednesday morning. Strong northwesterly winds and falling temperatures on Wednesday, will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve Wednesday night. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
